replies.body: Hello Abraham,  I'm sorry maybe I misunderstood the concepts. I'm running a Image based simulation like Mostapha shows in [this tutorial](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nI8pkTBeye0).  [](http://api.ning.com:80/files/x93ABI42iFWbzQ4kCdXtHY5wl45zQ1TXOivUVi3rmj35za7bNTBjaoD5JhXtlYZv6X*upHNHbHM5RQ48GT9UB8nUxJW1FAVw/Screenshotatsept27094551.png)

Ahhh!!

I was thinking you were using the LB_sunlightHoursAnalysis component. Now i see you are doing this in HB+Radiance. So my suggestion is to check the materials you are using and reduce the specularity or give a 0 value at all. Also check the reflectance of the material. There is a chance this is affecting the simulation.

-A.

I tried setting manually the material with this [Colour picker tool for radiance](http://www.jaloxa.eu/resources/radiance/colour_picker/index.shtml) This is my white opaque material Specularity = 0  Roughness = 0.2  Reflectance = 1 (I can't manage this parameter) [](http://api.ning.com:80/files/x93ABI42iFVSfcM9cBjYbGjG-C4Ywu3MQHXJbOF9-yHY4*7eyZ0*uzvBdRFUeISXzZEefGRgcB0MvmpW82*vc3pBL3IgiG67/Screenshotatsept27102612.png) **void plastic identifier**
**0**
**0**
**5 1 1 1 0 0.2**

[](http://api.ning.com:80/files/x93ABI42iFVYhYkDAu-I6NO2ihfy1XAgAjRGyB5t7iJ2OAhVCU2ynnwGKaOJTFl5fXGvkwGbSNt1W8hX9djxACFLQY4qkPKt/Screenshotatsept27103508.png) Is there another way to reduce this shinny effect?[](http://api.ning.com:80/files/x93ABI42iFVYhYkDAu-I6NO2ihfy1XAgAjRGyB5t7iJ2OAhVCU2ynnwGKaOJTFl5fXGvkwGbSNt1W8hX9djxACFLQY4qkPKt/Screenshotatsept27103508.png)

Are you using the HB_radOpaqueMaterial component. There you can set as you wish and need.

Uploading your file can be helpful.

-A.

That material is 100% reflective! That's why you get all that light spots. Try something less reflective: **void plastic identifier**
**0**
**0**
**5 **.5 .5 .5** 0 0.2**

I am not sure if the issue that you are facing is related to specularity or exposure....here is what happens if you change the exposure on a Radiance image. e = 0 [](http://api.ning.com:80/files/AgFOgF-tqnRlFVcM2A9WvOXxYoOpGiKOJuq-GZkU2jX3h6UxY5f07hOUaeWLmjt7z4c37SP64-3KCQkQ92aoK*PxLMo69Kz-/0.bmp) e= -1 [](http://api.ning.com:80/files/AgFOgF-tqnTDtl1KPC7kOVdIwZ1ZHFuRDglrbJZCWMYRwBDgix3G-XZkpSvwRs1iT46DBpeINIk348pvl3A-F-shMkgvFoFC/1.bmp)e=-2 [](http://api.ning.com:80/files/AgFOgF-tqnQRd-qkRYHkYr3yijEuE52dZceFH7ng6gp6eNVkQfFQl5sUMMklWjuYnV3tPFC8YS2jl76NMYKqsOSlZn*mmWYt/2.bmp) e= -3 [](http://api.ning.com:80/files/AgFOgF-tqnTJdRb*jE1XmfIy9W4M-Uyur7Op7LQhtXjtIBZkWchHrjVskZdALxpwExwkkqra9pyRPttrRXpJ5u0Yffm3WUMO/3.bmp) e = -4 [](http://api.ning.com:80/files/AgFOgF-tqnS-z0FfY4Ad6L3znLmi8GDL6txsQIQBy6ztfrEk21Hk3zD1Qs0-dCLoSKdb6tyiKzb*qNAM2TZomvYJCeoBOtqM/4.bmp) Setting exposure values is a "post-processing" thing done to improve the display of the image on a device or photograph. So, your analysis will still be physically based. I think towards the end of his video Mostapha talks about how the exposure values can be set through Honeybee....

And that's why is always good to upload the example file.

Agree that this doesn't seem to be exposure issue. Still think this is a material definition one.

-A.
